questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2 to 8 mmHg. SpO2 was 90%. BP dropped to 80/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18cmH2O. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Venous CO2 gas embolism is a potentially fatal complication of laparoscopy that occurs when large CO2 gas bubbles enter the venous system, circulate to the heart, and result in right ventricular chamber gas lock and a subsequent venous outflow obstruction.
  • Although the consequence of CO2 embolism can be severe, clinically significant occurrence is rare.
  • The etiology of a venous CO2 gas embolism during laparoscopic surgery, and its degree of hemodynamic impact, is likely multifactorial. Direct Veress needle insertion into a vein or solid organ during insufflation could potentially result in CO2 entry into the venous system. Open, transected vessels during laparoscopic surgical dissection may result in sudden gas venous ingress and a CO2 gas embolism. Round ligament transection and broad ligament dissection during laparoscopic hysterectomy have resulted in gas embolisms. The deep dorsal venous complex is a major source of bleeding during radical prostatectomies and a potential source of gas embolism during vessel transection.
  • Vigilance is important for the early detection of a venous CO2 gas embolism. Diagnosis is usually dependent on the constellation of clinical signs associated with gas emboli. The severity and presence of these signs vary widely. Acute tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, QRS complex widening, hypotension, hypoxemia, and low-end-tidal CO2 may be seen by monitoring. Physical exam findings may include cyanosis and a "mill wheel" murmur by auscultation. TEE is considered the most sensitive method for detecting gas emboli in the heart.
  • Peak airway pressure of 18CmH2O is a normal value.
  • Airway pressure is not usually affected by carbon dioxide embolism.
  • Pneumothorax, endobronchial intubation and bronchospasm will have increased airway pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following agent can be used as sole agent for induction and intubation
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is the only agent among the options that can be used as a sole agent for induction and intubation due to its low blood-gas partition coefficient, making it fast-acting with minimal irritation to the airway. It is commonly used for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients, due to its non-pungent odor and rapid onset.

Incorrect Options:

  • Isoflurane: It is highly pungent, causing airway irritation, and is not suitable for inhalation induction.
  • Halothane: Though previously used for induction, it has been largely replaced by Sevoflurane due to concerns about hepatotoxicity and a slower onset.
  • Desflurane: It has a very pungent odor and can cause airway irritation and coughing, making it unsuitable for use as a sole induction agent.

Key Takeaway:

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for sole induction and intubation due to its rapid action, low airway irritation, and favorable safety profile, especially in pediatric populations.

questions.text: A patient after an RTA was received in the emergency department with the following cannula in the picture. What is the maximum flow rate of fluid through this cannula?
questions.solution:
Green can ual is 18G cannula , and its flow rate is 90-110 ml/ min , so the appropriate answer would be 96

Pink cannula which is 20 G , will have a flow rate of 55 to 60 ml/min

Grey cannula is 180 ml/min

Orange cannula is 240 ml/ min

Key takeaway:

questions.text: Maximum oxygen flow rate through conventional oxygen masks?
questions.solution:
Conventional oxygen masks, such as simple face masks or non-rebreather masks, are designed to deliver high oxygen flow rates to patients. The maximum oxygen flow rate varies depending on the mask type, but for conventional oxygen masks, the maximum oxygen flow rate is typically 15 liters per minute (L/min).

Details of Oxygen Delivery via Masks:

  1. Simple Face Mask:
    • Flow rate: 5-10 L/min
    • Oxygen concentration: 40%-60% FiO2
  2. Non-Rebreather Mask:
    • Flow rate: 10-15 L/min
    • Oxygen concentration: Up to 95% FiO2 (with proper fit and flow)
  3. Venturi Mask:
    • Flow rate: 4-12 L/min
    • Oxygen concentration: 24%-50% FiO2 (precise FiO2 control)
  4. Nasal Cannula:
    • Flow rate: 1-6 L/min
    • Oxygen concentration: 24%-44% FiO2

Why 15 L/min?

  • Most conventional oxygen masks (e.g., non-rebreather) are designed to function effectively with flow rates up to 15 L/min.
  • At flow rates higher than this, specialized devices like high-flow nasal cannulas (HFNC) or mechanical ventilators are required.

Key Takeaway:

The maximum oxygen flow rate deliverable through conventional oxygen masks is 15 L/min, making it ideal for providing high oxygen concentrations in emergency situations.

questions.text: During resuscitation, a patient received intralipid 20%, what could be the most probable cause of cardiac arrest
questions.solution:
Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST):

  • Cause:LAST occurs due to excessive systemic absorption or accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetics, such as lidocaine or bupivacaine.
  • Mechanism:Local anesthetics block sodium channels, leading to CNS excitation (seizures) followed by CNS depression, cardiovascular collapse, and cardiac arrest.
  • Treatment:Intravenous Intralipid 20% is the standard antidote, acting as a lipid sink to sequester the toxic local anesthetic from target tissues.

Incorrect Options:

  • A: Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA):
    • PEA is a clinical condition where there is electrical activity on ECG without a palpable pulse. It is not a direct indication for intralipid therapy.
    • Causes include hypoxia, hypovolemia, acidosis, and more, but not LAST.
  • B: Electrocution:
    • Electrocution can cause cardiac arrest due to arrhythmias like ventricular fibrillation or asystole, but it is not treated with intralipid.
  • D: Asphyxia due to Drowning:
    • Drowning causes hypoxia and cardiac arrest. Management focuses on oxygenation and ventilation, not intralipid.

Key Takeaway:

  • Intralipid 20%is the antidote for Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), a rare but serious complication of local anesthetics.
  • Recognize and differentiate LAST from other causes of cardiac arrest (PEA, electrocution, or asphyxia) to initiate appropriate treatment.

questions.text: THE IMMEDIATE COMPLICATIONS SEEN WITH THE FOLLOWING PROCEDURE IS?
questions.solution:
Left subclavian cannulation involves inserting a catheter through the subclavian vein. The subclavian artery lies close to the vein, making it prone to accidental puncture during the procedure.

  • Result: Arterial puncture can lead to immediate complications such as hematoma, bleeding, or hemothorax, which requires prompt management.

Incorrect Options:

  • B: Chylothorax:
    • Caused by damage to the thoracic duct, commonly associated with left-sided subclavian cannulation. However, it is a delayed complication, not an immediate one.
  • C: Thrombophlebitis:
    • An inflammatory response of the vein wall, typically associated with prolonged catheter placement or peripheral IV access. This is a late complication.
  • D: Empyema:
    • Refers to pus accumulation in the pleural space, usually due to infection, and is a delayed complicationof catheter-related infections.

Key Takeaway:

  • Arterial punctureis the most common immediate complication of left subclavian cannulation.
  • Use of ultrasound guidance can reduce the risk.

questions.text: MET equivalent of 1500 mL of oxygen consumption per minute for healthy 70 kg adult male with basal oxygen consumption of 250 ml per minute
questions.solution:
The MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities. One MET is defined as the oxygen consumption of 3.5 mL O2/kg/min, which is approximately 250 mL/min for a 70 kg adult male at rest.

Calculation:

  1. Oxygen Consumption: Given oxygen consumption = 1500 mL/min.
  2. Basal Oxygen Consumption: Basal oxygen consumption = 250 mL/min (1 MET).
  3. MET Equivalent: MET = Oxygen Consumption / Basal Oxygen Consumption
  4. MET = 1500 / 250 = 6

Incorrect Options:

  • 2 and 4: These values underestimate the actual oxygen consumption.
  • 10: This value overestimates the oxygen consumption for the given data.

Key Takeaway:

  • 1 MET = Basal oxygen consumption (250 mL/min for a 70 kg male).
  • For 1500 mL/min oxygen consumption, the MET equivalent is 6.

choices.text: From angle of mouth to the lower part of the earlobe tills xiphisternum
From tip of nose to below the earlobe till manubrium sternii
From tip of nose to ear lobule to midpoint between manubrium sternii and umbilicus
From the tip of nose to below the earlobe till umbilicus

questions.text: How is the measurement of nasogastric tube done?
questions.solution:
The correct method for measuring the length of a nasogastric tube (NGT) involves the following steps:

  1. Measure the distance from the tip of the nose.
  2. Extend the measurement to the earlobe.
  3. Continue to the umbilicus or the midpoint between the sternum and the umbilicus.

This ensures the tube reaches the stomach while minimizing complications such as coiling in the esophagus.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

  • A: From the angle of the mouth to the lower part of the earlobe till the xiphisternum: Incorrect because the NGT is measured starting from the nose, not the mouth, and the xiphisternum is not the correct endpoint.
  • B: From the tip of the nose to below the earlobe till the manubrium sternii: Incorrect as the manubrium sternii is too proximal to reach the stomach effectively.
  • C: From the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the midpoint between the manubrium sternii and umbilicus: This is partially correct but falls short of ensuring the NGT reaches the stomach.

Key Takeaway:

To ensure proper placement of the nasogastric tube, measure from the tip of the nose, to the earlobe, and finally to the umbilicus or a point between the sternum and the umbilicus.
